body: Compiling as C++ changes nothing semantically, but ensures that we don't break C++ compatibility while also retaining C compatibility. C++ compatibility is useful for tooling and additional diagnostics and analyses. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)

comment_regular_data.body:
Reviewed 2 of 2 files at r1.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions.

---

_[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KV_rD6xn1kT_5ATSiwJ:bqhkie7) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_

> ``` C
> #if defined(__MACH__)
>     int set = 1;
>     return (setsockopt(sock, SOL_SOCKET, SO_NOSIGPIPE, (const char *)&set, sizeof(int)) == 0);
> ```

 The fourth argument of `setsockopt` is of `const void *` type https://linux.die.net/man/2/setsockopt. Why use cast it to `const char *`?

---

_[toxcore/network.c, line 199 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rZCrUTIHWW-FtqmD:-KV_rZCsoJWzoSB5E1sW:bg2smhm) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L199)):_

> ``` C
>     int ipv6only = 0;
>     socklen_t optsize = sizeof(ipv6only);
>     int res = getsockopt(sock, IPPROTO_IPV6, IPV6_V6ONLY, (char *)&ipv6only, &optsize);
> ```

The fourth argument of `getsockopt`is of `void *` type https://linux.die.net/man/2/setsockopt. Why cast it to `char *`?

---

_Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KV_tCc5tUM5FVxyPlW0:b4rhh6g) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, nurupo wrote… > The fourth argument of `setsockopt` is of `const void *` type https://linux.die.net/man/2/setsockopt. Why use cast it to `const char *`? >
> Compatibility with the Windows version of `setsockopt`: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms740476(v=vs.85).aspx --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 199 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rZCrUTIHWW-FtqmD:-KV_t7yOWQOpYwkgFyVQ:btjqhnh) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L199)):_
Previously, nurupo wrote… > The fourth argument of `getsockopt`is of `void *` type https://linux.die.net/man/2/setsockopt. Why cast it to `char *`? >
> Compatibility with the Windows version of `getsockopt`: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms738544(v=vs.85).aspx --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

Reviewed 7 of 12 files at r2. Review status: 9 of 14 files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KVaO6y_da4832uGJXFa:b-h0jb7r) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, iphydf wrote… > Compatibility with the Windows version of `setsockopt`: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms740476(v=vs.85).aspx >
> Wouldn't this remove the type warning from Windows build of toxcore and introduce the type warning on the Linux build of toxcore? Also, it looks like you have undone your changes for this file in the PR. --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

Review status: 9 of 14 files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KVaQWtRuZNA4DOLVsJG:blnphm4) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, nurupo wrote… > Wouldn't this remove the type warning from Windows build of toxcore and introduce the type warning on the Linux build of toxcore? > > Also, it looks like you have undone your changes for this file in the PR. >
> No, because `T*` is implicitly convertible to `void*`. If windows and linux didn't agree about the signedness of their pointer arguments, that would be a problem, but linux uses `void*`, so casting something to `char*` is fine. --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

Review status: 9 of 14 files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KVaRV6mYwLJ1Vh0nDhC:bfgidl) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, iphydf wrote… > No, because `T*` is implicitly convertible to `void*`. If windows and linux didn't agree about the signedness of their pointer arguments, that would be a problem, but linux uses `void*`, so casting something to `char*` is fine. >
> Isn't `void*` also implicitly convertible to `T*`, or it's just in C, not in C++? For example, you generally don't cast the return value of malloc in C code, but you did that in the LAN_discovery.c in this PR. --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

Review status: 9 of 14 files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KVaT0NA8RydJgiQpNSo:bxjmzmh) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, nurupo wrote… > Isn't `void*` also implicitly convertible to `T*`, or it's just in C, not in C++? For example, you generally don't cast the return value of malloc in C code, but you did that in the LAN_discovery.c in this PR. >
> (Also, it looks like Reviewable has found network.c file this time. After your first comment the network.c file suddenly disappeared from Reviewable. Well, there was still a box for the file in Reviewable, but it had only the the comment threads, there were no lines of code in it, and it was saying something along the lines of this file not being in PR. Weird.) --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

Review status: 9 of 14 files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- _[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KVajL9NLydGqx_6phY5:b-vvctca) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, nurupo wrote… > (Also, it looks like Reviewable has found network.c file this time. After your first comment the network.c file suddenly disappeared from Reviewable. Well, there was still a box for the file in Reviewable, but it had only the the comment threads, there were no lines of code in it, and it was saying something along the lines of this file not being in PR. Weird.) >
> In C++, that implicit conversion is not valid. In C, you don't cast malloc, because in C you can have implicit declarations. In C++, you can't, so the reason not to cast malloc goes away (so we do cast malloc). --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

_[toxcore/network.c, line 173 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-KV_rD6wQ3m6AqAHghLU:-KVaobMAqtstKpW66Nvp:bmxfy3e) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a24a4a4d4dc198c258abc7f899fc2c07f4c315de/toxcore/network.c#L173)):_
Previously, iphydf wrote… > In C++, that implicit conversion is not valid. In C, you don't cast malloc, because in C you can have implicit declarations. In C++, you can't, so the reason not to cast malloc goes away (so we do cast malloc). >
> Ok. (Oh, it was "File not in pull request at selected revision.", i.e. it was just me not using Reviewable correctly.) --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227)_

--- Reviewed 5 of 12 files at r2. Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, all discussions resolved. --- _Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/227#-:-KVap8TcRN7sYIin7fX2:b-jbsf8z)_
Nice branch name btw, totally Windows :P

commit.message:
Compile as C++ for windows builds.

Compiling as C++ changes nothing semantically, but ensures that we don't
break C++ compatibility while also retaining C compatibility.

C++ compatibility is useful for tooling and additional diagnostics and
analyses.

Compile as C++ for windows builds.

Compiling as C++ changes nothing semantically, but ensures that we don't
break C++ compatibility while also retaining C compatibility.

C++ compatibility is useful for tooling and additional diagnostics and
analyses.
